title: Friday, 20th November, 2015

All that’s happened so far is that advisers to BAT have corralled together a syndicate of investment banks willing to support an offer — but with Imperial shares now trading near a record high the company might choose to go pens down rather than risk overpaying, they cautioned.

BE

BE

G4S PLC (GFS:LSE): Last: 220.66, down 5.14 (-2.28%), High: 225.60, Low: 217.30, Volume: 4.36m

BE

Such as yesterday, when G4S CFO Himanshu Raja had a "fireside chat" at a Cazenove conference.

BE

(We don't know if that involved an actual fire. If anyone attended, please let us know.)

11:18 am
BE

BE

G4S shares slumped.

PM

did he now

11:19 am
BE

His message seemed to be mix, rather than downgrade at group level .....

BE

........... But unless it's in an RNS, confusion has a tendency to creep in.

BE

Heres' the note Caz sent around halfway through yesterday.

11:19 am
BE

H115 organic revenue growth was 4.2%. Management expects growth at the 4% level for the year. At the time of the H1 results, management had thought that H2 growth could trend towards 5%, but emerging markets (c.40% of revenue) have slowed a bit, especially due to commodity softness, although growth here is still expected to be high single digit (from low double digit). The trends in developed markets have remained, with North America (c.20% of revenue) seeing good growth, Continental Europe (c.20% of revenue) seeing a return to growth and the UK & Ireland (c.20% of revenue) seeing a small decline, with the expectation of a pickup next year.

BE

[...] we have decided to use today to update our forecasts, moderating estimates for factors including FX moves and a more conservative assumption of emerging market growth (c40% of revenue). Our EPS estimates decline by 4% moving in FY15 from 15.4p to 14.8p (Bloomberg consensus 14.8p) and in FY16 from 17.4p to 16.7p (Bloomberg consensus 16.7p). Our estimates assume organic revenue growth of 4.1% in FY15 and 5.7% in FY16 and, after a margin of 6.3% in FY14, margins of 6.5% in FY15 and 6.7% in FY16. Also, we have moved from a PER-based price target to a DCF-based target as we believe that this better reflects the relative predictability of G4S. Our Dec-16 price target is 298p (from Dec-15 309p).

BE

And this morning we get a Credit Suisse downgrade, on identical themes.

11:20 am
BE

Downgrade to Neutral: We reduce our 2015-2017E EPS forecasts by 3-12% to reflect FX, growing headwinds in its emerging markets operations (40% of 2014 EBITA) and looming challenges within its cash solutions business (25% 2014 EBITA). These factors will, we think, limit both organic revenue growth rates and the impact of internal initiatives to improve efficiency. We downgrade to Neutral (from Outperform) and cut our target price to 250p (from 320p).

BE

■ Investment Case: We had expected that the combination of efficiency programs, cost reduction and investment into sales/business development would drive both robust organic growth and margin expansion. The pressures in emerging markets are, however, negatively impacting both growth and operational leverage. In addition, the shift away from cash to electronic payment systems will, we think, see incremental pressure in the cash division, particularly in developed markets. We expect that organic growth will be below the management's mid-term expectations of 5-8% in both 2015E and 2016E. The long term restructuring of the business continues to offer significant opportunities to improve returns across the operation but cyclical and structural headwinds will, we think, delay and limit the impact. We downgrade to Neutral.

BE

■ Valuation: Our DCF-derived target price declines to 250p (from 320p) to reflect lower near term forecasts and lower mid to longer term returns. At the current price, it trades at 15.3x 2016E PE and 12.7x EV/EBITA. We do see some valuation support from the 4.2% (2015E) dividend yield.

11:21 am
BE

I understand, and am largely sympathetic of, the arguments against quarterly reporting.

BE

However, price discovery would be helped by some easier way to informally communicate this stuff. Fireside chats don't seem an ideal mechanism.

PM

Cheers for that Bryce

PM

Shall we ahve an Autumn Statement interlude?

Some good Archer this morning

11:22 am
BE

Go on then.

PM

Got out of the habit of doing UK macro

PM

When is it?!

11:22 am
PM

Ah, 25th

NC

· Very disappointing and difficult news for Chancellor George Osborne to digest ahead of Wednesday’s Autumn Statement and Spending Review. Not only did public finances deteriorate year-on-year in October but it now looks hugely difficult for the Chancellor to meet his fiscal targets contained in July’s budget. This is even allowing for the fact that the public finances can be volatile from month to month (partly due to the timing of expenditures) and can be revised significantly.
· In fact, it was the worst October for the public finances since 2009
· October’s weakened public finances was the consequence of both disappointing receipts and a high month for government expenditure.
· October’s weakened performance meant that Public Sector Net Borrowing excluding banks was only down by 10.9% over the first seven months of fiscal year 2015/16 to £54.3 billion from £60.9 billion in April-October 2014.
· Consequently, George Osborne now has an almighty task to meet his fiscal targets for 2015/16. Indeed, if the pattern of the first seven months of the fiscal year continued, PSNBex would amount to £80.3 billion in 2015/16, which would mean that Mr. Osborne would overshoot by some £11 billion the target of £69.5 billion contained in his July budget
· Or to put it another way, barring major revisions, Public Sector Net Borrowing excluding banks needs to be limited to £15.2 billion between November and March to meet the on the Chancellor’s current target of £69.5 billion. This looks a pretty big ask as it would be a drop of £14.0 billion (47.9%) from the £29.2 billion shortfall seen during November 2014-March 2015.

NC

That's Howard Archer, he of the high-speed typing

11:23 am
PM

hmm

NC

Some might say the targets are a waste of time any way, but that's what Osborne has nailed his colours to

NC

Guessing about next week:

11:24 am
NC

NC

11:25 am

(@the legggie: as an oldie, I agree with you. Time we paid for our bus passes, train discounts, heating etc)

PM

Here's some Credit Suisse just to add to that

11:27 am
PM

Sonali Punhani

PM

Rather relaxed

PM

The UK Summer Budget smoothed out the pace of fiscal consolidation penciled in the
March budget and reduced the fiscal headwind to growth. It envisioned reaching a surplus
by 2019/20, with the rollercoaster path of public services spending cuts flattened, and
financed instead by welfare cuts and net tax increases.
The Autumn Statement next week (25th November) would be the third fiscal event of the
year. It will be accompanied by the Spending Review, where the department budgets are
expected to be announced. Per se, we expect it to be a political rather than an economic
event. We don’t expect much change in the path of fiscal consolidation and the headline
deficit numbers. Overall the Autumn Statement next week is unlikely to change our
outlook on UK growth or the pace of monetary policy normalization.
But a shift in where the savings are coming from is expected. The Summer Budget
committed to cut the welfare bill by £12bn in order to meet the surplus target. This
included £4bn worth of savings in tax credit cuts, which has been blocked by the House of
Lords and has become a politically sensitive topic. While the impact of the tax credit cuts is
somewhat mitigated by the introduction of the National Living Wage, it is far from complete,
as we discussed here.

11:27 am
PM

In our view, the Treasury is likely to reverse some of the tax credits cuts and find these
savings elsewhere. There are many possibilities:
1) Eyeing cuts in other benefits such as housing or universal credit, which is also
politically contentious.
2) Cutting public services further or raising taxes.
3) Lower inflation and interest rate expectations compared to the summer are
expected to generate £2bn of savings per year. The lower than expected cost of
servicing debt means that the cuts required to reach the target can be reduced,
giving the Treasury some headroom.
4) Reducing the surplus target of £10bn by 2019/20.

PM

In our view, the first two options look politically difficult. Public services outside the
protected areas already need to be cut by £20bn in the Spending Review and reports
show that spending on education and economic affairs is likely to reach record lows. As
Exhibit 2 shows, the Summer Budget pencils in a spending cut of 2% of GDP on
unprotected services by 2020-21.
Thus we expect the surplus in 2019/20 to be cut from £10bn to £8bn, with the impact
of the reversal in tax credit cuts somewhat mitigated by lower inflation and interest
rate expectations

undefined
11:28 am
BE

So, from austerity to luxury. The natural segue.

BE

Because Merrill has a big note out on luxury good makers on the back of an investor tour to China.

BE

Regular readers will know our general thesis here.

11:29 am
BE

As in, the slowdown in sector earnings growth is structural, not cyclical and that returns have peaked.

BE

Here's Merrill.

BE

We believe the slowdown in sector earnings growth is structural, not cyclical and that
returns have peaked.

11:30 am
BE

Our forecasts imply 5% EPS CAGR in the next three years, below the
broader European market as a result we argue for a sector de-rating. We reiterate our
underweight positioning on the sector and maintain our U/P ratings on LVMH,
Richemont & Swatch. Our Buy on Kering reflects its cheap valuation, self-help at Gucci
and potential sale of Puma to drive a rerating.

BE

Usual reasons. China slowdown, Hong Kong struggling, watches becoming less important as a category.

BE

And the gradual move by the consumer downmarket as everyone tries to move upmarket.

11:31 am
BE

Noted previously Burberry's plan to kill its low-end brand and just become "Burberry"

BE

Which, given the pyramid of sales volume, is an attempt to move upmarket. Look what happened to Mulberry when it tried the same.

BE

Anyway, here's Merrill's five observations from China.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

And here's its downgrade of Jimmy Choo -- which to remind still has a majority shareholder that is highly likely to sell out.

BE

Slower top-line to weigh on ST earnings; d/g to Neutral
We are lowering our 2015-17 EPS estimates by 22-24%, reflecting a more cautious topline
outlook in light of recent weak trends reported by peers, particularly in the US.
Lower revenue growth in 2015 should result in greater operating deleverage as the
business continues to rightly invest for the long-term. We reduce our PO to 165p (from
195p) implying 10% upside potential. While the long-term growth opportunities remain
intact, trading on 27.2x ‘16E PE, a 30% premium to mid-cap peers, we view the
risk/reward profile as less attractive and downgrade to Neutral.

11:33 am
BE

Tougher backdrop, particularly US, drags on growth
We reduce our top-line estimates for 2015-16 by 4-7% due to a more difficult
environment for luxury as reported by peers in Q3. The US was particularly
disappointing, to which Jimmy Choo generates approximately 30% of its sales, and
where our economists see increased macro risk. We expect a negative performance in
this market will lead to a deterioration in SSSG in H2 (-1.1% from +3.3% in H1).

BE

Margin expansion paused in 2015, to resume in 2016
The combination of softer top-line growth and continued investment in the store
network and brand will likely result in margin contraction in 2015. We forecast 2015
EBITDA of £50m, implying a margin of 15.7% (-109bps yoy) and EBIT of £32m (margin
10.2%, -155bps yoy). From 2016, as revenue growth picks-up and operating cost growth
slows, margin expansion should resume; we forecast a 27bps increase in EBIT margin.

BE

Long-term growth story on hold until macro abates
Jimmy Choo continues to offer an attractive long-term growth profile to peers, as it
benefits from channel, regional and product opportunities. We remain confident on the
relative resilience of the shoes category (versus other segments) and the margin upside
potential. However, near-term the challenging macro backdrop is likely to weigh on
earnings growth. As such we see limited upside in the shares on a 12-month view and
downgrade to Neutral.

11:34 am
PM

Would you go so far as to sell Black suited Goons, Bryce?

PM

PM

BE

BE

Countrywide first. Which I think is at or near a two-year low.

Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 389.00, down 10.7 (-2.68%), High: 396.90, Low: 385.90, Volume: 116.86k
11:39 am
BE

All of this will look quite familiar.

BE

Downgrade To Neutral – Whilst fundamentals regarding affordability still look
attractive, we have admittedly been too positive on the timing of the recovery in
housing transactions. A lack of supply is still holding back the sector. We also note
that Countrywide’s market share has been drifting slightly. As such we take a more
cautious stance, reducing estimates and cutting our recommendation to Neutral with
a revised target price of 425p (from 615p)

BE

Why's Countrywide losing market share?

11:40 am
BE

Citi puts it down to the private estate agents being more aggressive to capture limited volumes.

NC

That's quite a cut in the TP

BE

Haven't noticed anything in the note talking about the online estate agents offering to sell your house for a flat fee.

11:41 am
BE

Even though I see quite a lot of signs for them, particularly outside ~£1m properties.

BE

Back to Citi.

NC

Must be a factor, now that price discovery is so much easier

11:42 am
NC

(except in Kinghtsbridge, of course)

BE

Yeah, and the traditional estate agent process is mostly pointless work creation.

BE

(From my own, limited, experience.)

11:43 am
BE

Here's Citi's working.

BE

 Long-Term Plan Remains Compelling – We remain of the view that the UK
housing market should see a cyclical recovery in sales volumes which should
benefit Countrywide. UK estate agency also remains a highly fragmented industry.
We continue to believe that Countrywide’s plan to double the size of the business,
largely through consolidation remains an attractive mid-term proposition.

BE

 Near-Term Supply Constraints Remain – Across the UK however there are
ongoing supply constraint issues impacting both sales and lettings instructions.
Sales properties listed per agent are limited at pre-election levels. Lettings are also
constrained as tenants chose to renew, and pay a modest uplift, rather than risk
trying to secure another property. Homes advertised to-let are currently -8% YoY.

11:43 am
BE

 Estimates Reduced, Valuation Attractive, But Risks Remain – Within the note
we cut our estimates following the recent weak Q3 update. Revenues for FY15 are
reduced -2%, FY16 -3% and FY17 -4%, leading to EBITDA -11%, -11% and -11%
respectively given the operational gearing of the enterprise. On these reduced
assumptions we suggest the stock remains fairly valued, especially compared to
peers, on 11.2x FY Dec16e p/e, 7.6x EV/EBITDA. We also remain of the view the
stock is well positioned to benefit from a cyclical recovery in housing transactions
and suggest the mid-term strategy to double the size of the business by 2020
makes sense. Whilst this is all positive, given the lack of near-term visibility on sales
and letting transaction volumes we reduce our recommendation to Neutral for now.

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 1.40, up 0.2117 (+17.82%), High: 1.65, Low: 1.29, Volume: 100.80m

BE

11:46 am
BE

Was really hoping for a rebellion. Tell the debtholders to wear the risk.

NC

BE

11:47 am
BE

Anyway, if you want to bet on platinum rallying this is a way to do so.

NC

11:48 am
BE

PM

BE

11:48 am
BE

Lonmin’s shareholders yesterday voted in support of the resolutions required to proceed with the fully underwritten US$407m rights issue. We update our price target to reflect the share trading “ex-rights” from today. The purely mechanical adjustment divides our unchanged valuation for equity over the enlarged number of shares (from 587m to 27.6bn), which results in an updated price target of SAc60ps and GBp2.8ps. Our equity valuation, with a rising price deck, is $1.3bn (significant upside), but our NPV at spot is negative and our Buy recommendation is purely a call on higher Rand-PGM prices.

BE

The market cap plus net cash raised over new shares (587m in issue plus 27bn to be issued) gives a theoretical ex-rights price (TERP) of SAc25.2ps GBp1.2ps based on 19 November 2015 closing price. This implies a value per right (each right allows for the purchase of a further 46 Lonmin shares at GBp1ps SAc21.4ps) of GBp8.7ps and SAc177ps.

BE

A successful rights issue provides Lonmin with c.US$450m in liquidity (net cash proceeds of the rights issue of US$369m add unutilised facilities of US$86m). Retrenchment costs are $59m and capex for the next three years is US$430m (US$132/110/188m over FY16/17/18e). Thus, if Lonmin’s cost and basket price are equal (as was the case in FY15) then available liquidity will be spent within three years on capex. It is our view that Lonmin needs higher Rand-PGM prices to have a sustainable business case. Lonmin is currently running its business on the hope that higher prices arise before a liquidity crunch arises, again.

11:48 am
BE

The rights issue closes on 10 December 2015 and the new shares will be issued on 11 December 2015. Lonmin will run a 100:1 share consolidation on 18 December 2015 to reduce the number of shares in issue.

BE

We derive our PT using a SOTP DCF (WACC 10% 0.9x NPV). We require higher Rand- PGM prices to obtain a positive valuation for Lonmin.

BE

That's the weirdest buy case I've ever read.

11:49 am
BE

"Business is broken unless something outwith anyone's control happens. But it might happen, so buy."

BE

Whatever. Make your own choices. Not my problem.

NC

our equity valuation, with a rising price deck, is $1.3bn (significant upside),

11:49 am
NC

BE

I dunno. Dunno. Meh.

undefined
11:50 am
PM

BE

BE

11:51 am
BE

BE

However, there was a request for the Citi downgrade earlier.

BE

Happy to help.

11:51 am
ICAP PLC (IAP:LSE): Last: 511.50, up 3 (+0.59%), High: 517.50, Low: 506.50, Volume: 509.31k
BE

Did I say downgrade? Clearly, i meant upgrade.

PM

(alewis2005 -- good question)

11:52 am
BE

 The Inevitable Conclusion — Consolidation of the Interdealer Broker (‘IDB’)
market seemed inevitable. Low volatility and a lack of risk appetite from banks and
trading firms have left IDB volumes, and revenues, challenged. The agreed merger
of ICAP’s Global Broking division and Tullett Prebon, therefore, makes sense. For
‘tp-ICAP’, we see material cost synergies as achievable; for ICAP ‘NewCo’, we
expect benefits from a capital-lite business model, free from the burdens of its FCA
waiver, now with room to maneuver.

BE

 Looking to History for Similar Deals — We have looked at previous IDB deals
including Garban & Intercapital and Collins Stewart Tullett & Prebon. In each case,
cost synergies were offset by revenue losses from overlapping brokerage
operations. Therefore, we include revenue dis-synergies in our scenarios. The
£60m of cost synergies guided by the company appear low in a historic context,
also. Therefore, we assume £100m of cost synergies as our base assumption.
 Bull, Bear, Base — We set out scenarios in this note to reflect our assumptions
outlined above, i.e. cost synergies offset by revenue losses. Our Bull Case assumes
£150m cost synergies and no revenue losses. Our Base Case assumes £100m cost
synergies and £50m of revenue losses. Our Bear Case assumes £60m cost
synergies and £50m of revenue losses.

BE

 Tullett: Neutral, 390p Target Price — We value Tullett on a pro-forma basis,
assuming the deal completes. We value the pro-forma earnings on 11x to derive an
end FY’16 target price. Bull Case: 490p; Base Case: 390p; Bear Case: 340p. Our
target price is set on base-case assumptions.
 ICAP: Upgraded to Buy, 575p Target Price — In our pro-forma base-case SOTP:
we value Post-Trade business on 18x FY’18e earnings; Electronic Markets
business on 16x FY’18e earnings and assign a value of 180p per share from Tullett
shares to be issued. Bull Case: 670p; Base Case: 575p; Bear Case: 505p. Our
target price is set on base-case assumptions.
 ICAP Implied PE — Taking ICAP’s current share price, and deducting the implied
value of Tullett’s share price, under our Base Case scenario, suggests the residual
ICAP business is trading on ~15x FY’17e earnings – unchanged from the pre-deal

BE

[1] Slower growth for longer in Chinese luxury consumption
There has been no improvement in recent (weak) trends in Greater China. The Chinese
consumer was ‘flat-to-negative’ in Q3 and October trading has remained difficult
despite an easier comparison base. Industry feedback suggests a reacceleration in
Chinese demand for luxury in 2016 is unlikely.

[2] HK revenues remain under pressure, but relief to come from rent deflation
Hong Kong revenues are down 15-25% in Q3. The outlook for the rest of the year
remains tough and HK is likely to continue to lose share in 2016. However operating
profit deleverage may be lower than 2015 as some rent reductions are being achieved
(20-30% on high streets or 10-15% for larger flagships). Rents are still going up in
malls.

[3] Demand for watches remains soft, inventory still elevated
Watches continue to be the weakest product category in luxury, expected to be down
over 15% in H2. A higher level of discounting is going on as inventory remains elevated.
Retailers now plan to close stores in next 12 months, removing a stocking event.

[4] Momentum diverging in soft luxury, digital will be a key differentiator
Momentum at Gucci is picking up, Prada remains the notable underperformer while the
picture for Louis Vuitton was more mixed. Brands with strong RTW such as Saint
Laurent and Givenchy are becoming more popular. Digital was highlighted as a key
opportunity to drive traffic and conversion, although most brands are not yet equipped.

[5] Offshore consumption will continue. Korea boost from more duty free licenses
Tourism driven luxury spend will continue to be a very important theme; however comps
are tough in Japan & Europe, meaning it will likely be less supportive in 2016. Korea will
see increased demand as the MERS concerns fade and three new duty free malls open.
